item.title: Middle East Crisis: Harris Expresses Support for Israel but Says She ‘Will Not Be Silent’ About Palestinian Suffering
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a day after addressing Congress, met on Thursday with Vice President Kamala Harris and President Biden separately at the White House at a time when the future of the Middle East is on the line.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In Burkina Faso, ‘Nowhere Is Safe’ from Terrorists or Troops
item.description: The West African nation of Burkina Faso was once known for its lively arts scene. Now, it is a country torn apart by Islamist extremists and the government’s brutal effort to drive them out.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Guerchom Ndebo
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Guerchom Ndebo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Armed Forces Museum in Bobo-Dioulasso, Burkina Faso, during a cultural festival in May. Western countries like France and the United States once saw the nation as a haven of stability in a volatile region.

item.title: Racheal Kundananji Leads Zambia Against USWNT at Paris 2024
item.description: In seven years, Racheal Kundananji went from playing her first organized game to signing a multimillion-dollar contract. Her rise could have lasting effects.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Racheal Kundananji in Lusaka, Zambia, months after she signed a record-setting deal to join a team in the United States.

item.title: What a Professor’s Firing Shows About Sexual Harassment in China
item.description: A top Chinese university described the conduct of a professor accused of sexual harassment as a moral failing, language feminists say downplays harm to women.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Graduates at Renmin University in Beijing in 2023. The university has faced public scrutiny after a graduate student complained about her professor.

item.title: Why Only 15 Athletes From Russia Will Compete at the Paris Olympics
item.description: Only 15 athletes from Russia will compete at the Paris Games, under a “neutral” designation. The Kremlin is framing the ban as part of its showdown with Western adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Members of a Ukrainian group protest the decision by the International Olympic Committee to allow some Russian athletes to compete under a neutral flag at the Paris Olympics.

item.title: Ukraine Detains Suspect in Killing of Iryna Farion
item.description: An 18-year-old suspect was arrested after an intense manhunt. The authorities are investigating evidence that suggests that the suspect planned the killing with others.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Relatives of Iryna Farion, a Ukrainian lawmaker killed by a gunman last week, during her funeral in Lviv in July.

item.title: How the Summer Olympics Turned Paris Into a Security Fortress
item.description: Even if Paris weren’t scarred by terrorist attacks, protecting the opening ceremony, which will float down the Seine, offers a daunting challenge.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: French security forces, as well as police from Germany, South Korea and Brazil, walked the streets of the Montmartre neighborhood in Paris.

item.title: Divers in Baltic Find What Looks Like Champagne on Shipwreck
item.description: Polish divers think they have found cases of Champagne on a 19th-century merchant vessel that sank off Sweden.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: U.K. Policy on Israel’s War in Gaza Is Diverging From the U.S.
item.description: Britain’s new government is likely to withdraw objections to the International Criminal Court prosecutor’s pursuit of a warrant for Benjamin Netanyahu, two people told The Times.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Ministers Rishi Sunak of Britain and Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in London. The new British government is more likely to put pressure on Israel over its military response to the Oct. 7 attacks.

item.title: Russia and China Conduct First Joint Bomber Patrol Near Alaska
item.description: Two Russian and two Chinese bombers patrolled the airspace near American territory and were intercepted by U.S. and Canadian jets.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian military on Thursday purporting to show a Chinese bomber, left, and a Russian fighter jet during a joint patrol exercise near Alaska the previous day.

item.title: Why Planes Crash So Often in Nepal
item.description: Each new disaster, including a crash that killed 18 people on Wednesday, leads to another investigation. A serious conflict of interest is always left unaddressed.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: An airplane flying over the wreckage of a Saurya Airlines aircraft on Thursday in Kathmandu, Nepal.

item.title: Martin S. Indyk, Diplomat Who Sought Middle East Peace, Dies at 73
item.description: As ambassador to Israel in the Clinton administration and as a special envoy under Barack Obama, he was skeptical of Israeli settlements.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Mr. Indyk testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in October 1999. “His passion for making peace drove him,” said a fellow member of the Clinton administration.

item.title: Prince Harry Says Battle With U.K. Tabloids Deepened Family Rift
item.description: In a TV interview airing on Thursday, Harry said his dispute with British newspapers over illegal information gathering was a “central piece” of his estrangement from other royals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving court in London last year after giving evidence at the Mirror Group phone-hacking trial.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress: Key Takeaways
item.description: Here are six takeaways from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to U.S. lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking to American lawmakers on Wednesday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A new poll from the U.S. presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A new Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris faring better with young and nonwhite voters than President Biden had.

item.title: As Starvation Spreads in Sudan, Military Blocks Aid Trucks at Border
item.description: A country torn apart by civil war could soon face one of the world’s worst famines in decades, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: The Olympics You Remember Are Back
item.description: Family, friends and fans were missing from two straight Covid Games. In Paris, one athlete said, competitors will have the kind of experience they dream about.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.category: United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stands are filled at rugby sevens on the first day of competition.

item.title: In Japan, Turning the Tables on Rude Customers
item.description: The country is famous for its hospitality. But businesses have had enough of people screaming at workers or tormenting them on social media.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuji Tanaka, managing director at Yumori Tanakaya, talking to a guest during check-in time in Nasushiobara, Japan, last month.

item.title: Vintage of War
item.description: A single image captures the change in fortunes for a wine cellar turned field hospital in Russian-occupied Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Nanna Heitmann and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Breaking Down Netanyahu’s Speech in Congress
item.description: In his fourth speech to Congress, a record for a foreign leader, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel attempted to change the narrative about the fallout from the war in Gaza. Patrick Kingsley, the Jerusalem bureau chief for The New York Times, explains how Netanyahu used the speech to shift the focus to Iran and the threat it poses to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Farah Otero-Amad, Nikolay Nikolov, Rebecca Suner, Claire Hogan and James Surdam

item.title: 2 Top Leaders of Mexico’s Sinaloa Cartel, Including ‘El Mayo,’ in U.S. Custody
item.description: The two men, Ismael Zambada García and Joaquín Guzmán López, helped run the Sinaloa Cartel, one of the most dominant criminal groups in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Ismael Zambada García, known as El Mayo, has been pursued by the U.S. government for years.

item.title: Israel Retrieves Bodies of 5 Hostages From Tunnel in Gaza
item.description: The military said that intelligence, including information from detained Palestinian militants, had led to the bodies in the Khan Younis area.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Anjana Sankar
item.media:description: The funeral in Tel Aviv on Thursday of Kiril Brodski, a soldier and one of the hostages whose body was recovered from Gaza.

item.title: See the Wildfires Burning Across Western Canada and the Pacific Northwest
item.description: Fires burned hundreds of thousands of acres in California, Oregon and Alberta, causing evacuations and blanketing cities in smoke.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters battled flames from the Park fire in Chico, Calif.

item.title: Trump Urges Netanyahu to End War in Gaza Ahead of Friday Meeting
item.description: The Israeli leader is scheduled to visit Mar-a-Lago in Florida before he returns home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and former president Donald J. Trump at the White House in 2020.

item.title: At Least 30 Are Reported Killed in Khan Younis in 24 Hours
item.description: Israeli forces pressed forward in the southern Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Anjana Sankar
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman being carried into Nasser Hospital after strikes in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The Olympics Begin
item.description: Plus, a new poll shows Kamala Harris closing in on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Florian Hulleu/Paris 2024, Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A rendering of the opening ceremony of the Paris Games.

item.title: Half of Canadian Town Jasper Destroyed by Fast-Moving Wildfire
item.description: As much as half of Jasper, Alberta, which lies inside one of the country’s most-visited national parks, has been destroyed, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Le Minh Khue, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People evacuating Jasper National Park in Canada on Monday.

item.title: Sylvain Saudan, ‘Skier of the Impossible,’ Is Dead at 87
item.description: His audacious descents around the world inspired a generation of extreme skiers. “One mistake,” he once said, “you die.”
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Sylvain Saudan in Switzerland in 1970. In careening down alarmingly steep, previously untraversed slopes, he helped create an entirely new sport: extreme skiing.

item.title: Harris Offers Support for Israel but Calls Out Palestinians’ Plight After Talk With Netanyahu
item.description: A meeting with the Israeli prime minister amounted to a debut on the world stage for the vice president since her rapid ascension as the presumptive Democratic nominee for president.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the White House complex on Thursday.

item.title: The Taxidermy Bat Market Is Compounding Threats to a Species’ Existence
item.description: Online sales appear to be compounding threats from climate change and habitat loss, according to new research.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A study on the wildlife trade published this month focused on painted woolly bats because their distinctive orange fur and striped wings make them easy to identify in online listings.

item.title: 2024 Paris Olympics: What to Know and How to Watch Opening Ceremony
item.description: Gymnastics. Track. Swimming. Basketball. Break dancing.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympics come to Paris.

item.title: AlphaProof, a New A.I. from Google DeepMind, Scores Big at the International Math Olympiad
item.description: A.I. is getting good at math — and might soon make a worthy collaborator for humans.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Israeli security officials hope Biden will push Netanyahu to drop some demands in cease-fire talks.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Palestinians on foot after crossing from Gaza City to the southern Gaza Strip earlier this month.

item.title: Israeli Officials Retrieve the Bodies of 5 Hostages From Gaza
item.description: The military said that the bodies had been found in the Khan Younis area and that intelligence, including information from detained Palestinian militants, had led its forces to them.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip last month. The Israeli military said that five bodies were found in the Khan Younis area on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza’s Death Toll Was Largely Accurate in Early Days of War, Study Finds
item.description: Though the war has clearly devastated the civilian population, the credibility of the Gazan Health Ministry’s toll has been a subject of debate.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck held the bodies of Palestinians killed by Israeli airstrikes in central Gaza in October.

item.title: Australian Field Hockey Player Amputates Finger to Play in Paris Olympics
item.description: After the tip of his ring finger was mangled in a practice match two weeks ago, Matthew Dawson chose amputation over a long, uncertain recovery.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Yoon
item.media:description: Australia’s Matthew Dawson, in orange, during a match in June.

item.title: Philippines Says Tanker Carrying 1.4 Metric Tons Of Oil Capsizes In Manila Bay
item.description: The coast guard rescued 16 of the vessel’s 17 crew members, but Typhoon Gaemi’s remnants were complicating efforts to contain the oil spill in Manila Bay.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Philippine Coast Guard, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The tanker Terra Nova in Manila Bay on Thursday, in a photo released by the Philippine Coast Guard.

item.title: Typhoon Gaemi Reaches China as Cargo Ship Sinks Off Taiwan
item.description: The storm, weaker but still dangerous, made landfall just before 8 p.m. local time. Six sailors were still missing after a cargo ship sank near Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May, Amy Chang Chien and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: The Xindian River in New Taipei City, Taiwan, on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Why Biden quit the race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Nothing — nothing — can come in the way of saving our democracy,” President Biden said from the Oval Office. “That includes personal ambition.”

item.title: How US Chips Continue to End Up in Russian Missiles
item.description: Defying sanctions, Russia has obtained nearly $4 billion in restricted chips since the war began in Ukraine. Many were shipped through a cluster of shell companies in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: 135 Bonham Strand in Hong Kong houses shell companies that ship restricted military technology to Russia, according to an analysis by The New York Times.

item.title: Assessing Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
item.description: Some of his remarks have been disputed by human rights groups, and others are unverifiable or lacked context. Here’s a closer look.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended Israel’s war with Hamas on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Rolls Into Paris Olympics Amid Cheers, Boos and Police Sirens
item.description: France has promised an unusually heavy blanket of security for Israeli athletes at the Games. In its first test, it pulled out all the stops.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s soccer team made its competitive debut against Mali at the Paris Games.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Netanyahu’s Address to Congress
item.description: Plus, disinformation floods the internet during the U.S. presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the U.S. Capitol yesterday.

item.title: Netanyahu Defends Israel in Speech to Congress
item.description: The speech by Israel’s leader was charged with symbolism, as the war in Gaza has divided lawmakers. He portrayed the conflict as a proxy fight with Iran that must be won at all costs and condemned protesters.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s address laid bare deep divisions in Washington over the nine-month war, whose toll on civilians has outraged many Democrats and drawn international condemnation.

item.title: Protesters Denounce Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress and Some Clash With Police
item.description: Thousands of peaceful protesters gathered west of the Capitol, and smaller breakoff groups clashed with the police nearby and outside Union Station. Fifteen people were arrested, the Capitol Police said.
item.dc:creator: Maya C. Miller, Robert Jimison and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Act Now to Stop War and End Racism (ANSWER)
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators outside the Capitol on Wednesday before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was to address Congress.

item.title: Kamala Harris’s Indian Heritage Is Deeply Felt if Little Advertised
item.description: Many Indian Americans see Kamala Harris as another example of the diaspora’s success and influence.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at the White House last year. At a luncheon, Ms. Harris spoke of her personal connection to India.

item.title: When the Paris Olympics Begin, the Seine Is His Stage
item.description: To open the Games, the theater director Thomas Jolly has masterminded a spectacular waterborne ceremony depicting 12 scenes from French history.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Jolly, artistic director of all four Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies, in Paris. “I don’t have a model to work from,” he said. “It’s creation in the extreme.”

item.title: New Zealand Abuse in Care Report Speaks of ‘National Catastrophe’
item.description: The head of a six-year investigation into mistreatment in orphanages, mental health institutions and elsewhere said it found an “unthinkable national catastrophe” unfolding over decades.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: A crowd gathered at Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, for the release of an inquiry’s report into the abuse of children and vulnerable adults in state- and faith-based institutions over decades.

item.title: Salt Lake City Will Host 2034 Winter Olympics
item.description: Olympic officials insisted on the right to pull the Games amid U.S. investigations into how the World Anti-Doping Agency handled positive tests for banned substances among Chinese swimmers.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee
item.media:description: Members of the Salt Lake City 2034 delegation after Wednesday’s vote in Paris.

item.title: Meet the Woman Leading Venezuela’s Opposition to Maduro
item.description: Spurned by the country’s authoritarian president and even her own colleagues in the opposition, María Corina Machado has built the most significant voter mobilization since Hugo Chávez.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: María Corina Machado campaigning last week in Guanare, Venezuela. Polls show enormous support for her movement ahead of Sunday’s election.

item.title: Hepatitis A and Other Diseases Surge Among Gaza’s Displaced, U.N. Says
item.description: More than 100,000 people are suspected to have contracted hepatitis A, while polio, a disease that has been eradicated in much of the world, is now present there, according to the World Health Organization.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Children walking near stagnant wastewater on their way to a food distribution point in Deir al Balah, in central Gaza, last week.

item.title: Paris, City of Light and Shadows, Is Redrawn for the Olympics
item.description: The Games will usher visitors through France’s history, with events at the Grand Palais and Versailles. But, as host, Paris is also becoming a new city.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and James Hill
item.media:description: An American marching band visits the Eiffel Tower in June. The Paris landmark will loom over beach volleyball matches at the Olympic Games. Many of Paris’s historical sites will host events.

item.title: Germany Bans Islamic Group, Accusing it of Supporting Hezbollah
item.description: The authorities also searched dozens of properties linked to the Islamic Center Hamburg, which has long faced accusations of being a front for the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Nancy Faeser, Germany’s interior minister, accused the I.Z.H. of promoting Islamic extremism.

item.title: Nepal Plane Crash Kills 18 People After Takeoff
item.description: The pilot of the Saurya Airlines flight, which was departing from Kathmandu, was the only survivor, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Yan Zhuang

item.title: North Korean Trash Balloons Land on South Korean Leader’s Compound
item.description: Officials found nothing hazardous in the balloons’ payloads, as the North’s slow barrage of airborne garbage showed few signs of letting up.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cleaning up the payload of a balloon from North Korea that landed in a Seoul street on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s rally in Wisconsin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris told supporters in Milwaukee that “the baton is in our hands.”
